title: Esther McVey said that PM's past girlfriends won't affect his appeal
text:
Housing Minister Esther McVey has said that Boris Johnson is 'box office' and that voters don't care about his 'girlfriends'

Boris Johnson's past behaviour won't hurt him in the polls and voters 'don't care about his girlfriends,' Housing Minister Esther McVey has said.

Scandal has besieged the Prime Minister over his 'colourful' past since he took over at Downing Street from Theresa May in July this year.

Johnson's link to US tech entrepreneur, Jennifer Arcuri, is currently under a police watchdog investigation after she loaned more than £700,000 to her own company before being awarded a £100,000 government grant.

It is alleged that she received favourable treatment due to her 'friendship' with Johnson, who was London Mayor at the time.

There are further allegations that the two of them shared a sexual relationship.

McVey, however, believes this is of little concern to voters and that his personality will veer them away from the gossip about his private life.

'Boris is box office. He uplifts the spirits, he is a bon viveur...I think despite the difference in background they see him as someone they can relate to, they think he says it as it is,' she told the Times newspaper.

'They don't care about his girlfriends.'

Sunday Times journalist Charlotte Edwardes (pictured left) said that Boris Johnson (pictured right) grabbed 'enough inner flesh beneath his fingers' to make her 'sit upright' during a private lunch when he was the editor of the Spectator magazine in 1999. She also alleged that he did the same to another woman there

Further to the alleged sexual relationship with Jennifer Arcuri, Sunday Times columnist Charlotte Edwardes has accused Johnson of squeezing her thigh under a table in 1999 when he was the editor of the Spectator magazine.

She said that he grabbed 'enough inner flesh beneath his fingers' to make her 'sit upright' and said that he did the same to another woman attending the private lunch.

Johnson categorically denied the accusations.

According to polling, women are less likely than men to vote for him yet, McVey doesn't feel as though he has an issue with women.

'If Boris walks down the road people run along to have a selfie with him. Whether he is on his bike or getting into a cab he has a draw,' she said.

Speaking of the sexual harassment claims levied at him by journalist Charlotte Edwardes, she added: 'It was categorically denied. People are questioning the timing. People know he has had a colourful past, this isn't working against him.'
description: Boris Johnson's past behaviour won't hurt him in the polls as voters see him as 'box office' and they 'don't care about his girlfriends,' according to Housing Minister Esther McVey.
